facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 815 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION, Civil Appeal No. 815 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 23, 1963 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in 1st Appeal No. 23 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 23, 1963, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in 1st Appeal No. 23 of 1963.
December 20, 1963. The following Judgments were delivered AYYANGAR J.-On behalf of the Chief Justice and himself

facts.text: Appellant was elected to the House of the People from the Mahasamund parliamentary constituency in the State of Madhya Pradesh in the third general elections.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was elected to the House of the People from the Mahasamund parliamentary constituency in the State of- Madhya Pradesh in the third general elections.

facts.text: Respondents were the other contesting candidates.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were the other contesting candidates. Respondent 1 filed an election petition before the Election Commissioner of India

facts.text: Respondent 1 filed an election petition before the Election Commissioner of India under ss. 80 and 81 of the Act and it was duly referred to the Election Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent 1 filed an election petition before the Election Commissioner of India under ss. 80 and 81 of the Act for setting aside the election of the appellant and it was duly referred to the Election Tribunal.

facts.text: Election Tribunal dismissed the election petition by order dated January 5, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal, by its order dated January 5, 1963, dismissed the election petition.

facts.text: First respondent preferred an appeal against the order of the Election Tribunal to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur on February 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On February 11, 1963, the first respondent preferred an appeal against the said order of the Election Tribunal to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh at Jabalpur.

facts.text: Appeal was filed more than 30 days from the date of the Tribunal's order.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the appeal was filed more than 30 days from the said order.

facts.text: If time requisite for obtaining a copy of the order of the Tribunal was excluded, the appeal was filed within 30 days.

anchor.surface_text: If the time requisite for obtaining a copy of the order of the Tribunal was excluded, the appeal was filed within 30 days but if in law it could not be excluded,

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's plea that respondent 1 was not entitled to exclude time for obtaining copy.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant contended before the High Court that respondent I was not entitled in law to exclude the time so taken by him in obtaining a copy of the order of the Tribunal, but that plea was rejected by the High Court.

facts.text: High Court held that appellant committed two acts of corrupt practice under s. 123(4) of the Act and declared election void.

anchor.surface_text: On merits, the High Court held that the appellant had committed two acts of corrupt practice as defined by s. 123(4) of the Act and on that finding it declared the election of the appellant void.

facts.text: Facts relevant to the question raised are not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: The facts relevant to the question raised lie in a small compass and they are not disputed.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal preferred against High Court order setting aside appellant's election.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal has been preferred by the appellant against the said order of the High Court setting aside his ,election.

facts.text: Every appeal under Ch. IVA of the Act shall be preferred within 30 days from date of Tribunal order under s.98 or s.99.

anchor.surface_text: Under sub-s. (3) of s. 116-A of the Act every appeal under Ch. IVA of the Act shall be preferred within a period of thirty days from the date of the order of the Tri- bunal under s. 98 or s. 99 thereof.

facts.text: High Court proceeded on basis that s.29(2)(a) applies to appeals under s.116A of Representation of the People Act and held appeal within time after deducting s.12 time.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court have proceeded on the basis that s. 29(2)(a) applies to the case of appeals preferred under s. 116A of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 and on that footing have held that the appeal presented to them by the respondent was within time if computed after making the deductions permitted by s. 12 of the Limitation Act.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of s.12 of the Limitation Act can be invoked for computing the period of 30 days prescribed under s.116A(3) of the Representation of the People Act

anchor.surface_text: The only question, therefore, is whether for the purpose of computing the period of 30 days prescribed under s. 116A 3  of the Act the provisions of s. 12 of the Limitation Act can be invoked.

This relates to the relationship or inter-connection between the first and the second limbs of s. 29 2  of the Limitation Act.

issues.text: Whether an appeal under s.116A RPA is an appeal 'under the Code of Civil Procedure' for the purposes of Article 156 of the Limitation Act

arguments.court_reasoning: SC upholds application of s.12 via s.29(2)

arguments.claim: Two limbs of s.29(2) independent; second limb applies generally to any special law period without first limb condition

anchor.surface_text: Apart from the grammatical construction ... the conjunction and is used in different contexts. It may combine two sentences dealing with the same subject without one depending upon the other.

arguments.claim: Art.156 applies only to appeals where right conferred by CPC s.96, not special laws even if procedure CPC

anchor.surface_text: Where the right of appeal is given by some other law, the appeal must be regarded as one under that law and not under the Code.

arguments.claim: First limb s.29(2) requires positive period in Schedule; omission not 'prescribed period'

anchor.surface_text: I am of opinion that the first part of s. 29 2 of the Limitation Act applies only when a special or local law prescribes a period of limitation for an appeal and when for that particular appeal a period of limitation is prescribed in the First Schedule

arguments.claim: s.29(2) applies even if Schedule silent as special law provides limit where Schedule implies no limit

anchor.surface_text: When the First Schedule of the Limitation Act prescribes no time limit for a particular appeal, but the special law prescribes a time limit to it, can it not be said that under the First Schedule of the Limitation Act an appeal can be filed at any time, but the special law by limiting it provides for a different period?

arguments.claim: Second limb s.29(2) independent and applies to all special law periods

anchor.surface_text: With this last conclusion I agree. In my judgment what he has said on the last point is enough for the purpose of disposing of the appeal

arguments.claim: s.12(2) applies via s.29(2)(a) as High Court appeal under RPA follows CPC procedure per s.116A(2)

anchor.surface_text: Under the second part of sub-s. 2 of s. 116-A of the Act, a fiction is created, namely, that though a right of appeal is conferred by s. 116-A 1 of the Act, the appeal thereunder for the purpose of sub-s. 2 will be deemed to be an appeal from an original decree passed by a civil court

holdings.text: The provisions of section 12 of the Limitation Act apply to the computation of the 30-day period prescribed under section 116A(3) of the Representation of the People Act via section 29(2)(a).

anchor.surface_text: The only question, therefore, is whether for the purpose of computing the period of 30 days prescribed under s. 116A 3  of the Act the provisions of s. 12 of the Limitation Act can be invoked.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly applied s.29(2)(a); RPA prescribes 30 days different from 90 days under Art.156; s.116A(2) deems appeal under CPC procedure.

holdings.text: Article 156 of the First Schedule to the Limitation Act applies to appeals under s.116A RPA as they are appeals 'under the Code of Civil Procedure'.

anchor.surface_text: For this purpose he relied on Art. 156 of the first schedule which runs ----------------------------------------------------------- Time from which Description of Period of appeal limitation run ------------------------------------------------------------ 156.-Under the Code of Civil Ninety days The date of

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.116A(2) creates fiction equating to CPC appeal; follows Calcutta, Madras, Allahabad HCs; legislative practice.

holdings.text: s.29(2) first limb satisfied where special law prescribes period even if First Schedule silent, as 'different' from implied unlimited time.

anchor.surface_text: The contention urged strenuously before us by Mr. Pathak... we agree with Subba Rao J. in holding that the requirement... is satisfied in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Bombay HC Canara Bank and SC Kaushaliya; avoids anomaly of no s.3 application.

holdings.text: The two limbs of s.29(2) Limitation Act are cumulative; second limb applies only if first limb condition met.

anchor.surface_text: The last point which remains for consideration... we, therefore, hold that subject to the construction we have put upon sub-s. 2 of s. 29 both the parts are to be read as one whole

holdings.reasoning_summary: First part incomplete without second; avoids redundancy and anomaly; follows Raghubar Dayal J dissent in Sehat Ali.

holdings.text: Appeal under s.116A is 'under the Code of Civil Procedure' for Art.156 due to s.116A(2) deeming it CPC appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The argument was that though the right of appeal in the case before us was conferred by s. 116A of the Representation of the People Act... it was still an appeal under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, to a High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fiction in s.116A(2); Art.151 reference indicates procedure focus.

holdings.text: Election Tribunal order under s.98 RPA is a 'judgment' and 'order' for s.12(2) Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it is contended that s. 12 2 of the Limitation Act... In either view, s. 12 of the Limitation Act applies

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.90 RPA applies CPC procedure; order embodies judgment and formal decision; directly attracts s.12(2).

holdings.text: s.29(2) applies where First Schedule prescribes no period but special law does, as different from no limit.

anchor.surface_text: s. 116 A of the Representation of the People Act... the appeal presented to them by the respondent was within time if computed after making the deductions permitted by s. 12

holdings.reasoning_summary: Historical amendments resolve conflict; scheme of Limitation Act exhaustive; Canara Bank, Kaushaliya.

holdings.text: Second limb of s.29(2) independent, applies to any special law period without first limb condition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Any' thrice indicates generality; no anomaly as different categories.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.116A(3) does not exclude s.12; restores s.5 power excluded by s.29(2)(b).

holdings.text: Art.156 applies only to appeals where right conferred by CPC s.96, not special laws.

anchor.surface_text: Where the right of appeal is given by some other law, the appeal must be regarded as one under that law and not under the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No residuary for appeals; distinguishes procedure from right source.
